lines.text: Good artists copy, great artists steal.
We're better than you are! We have better stuff.
You don't get it, Steve. That doesn't matter!
Success is a menace. It fools smart people into thinking they can't lose.
Maybe fun is just fragments of existence with better packaging.
What is this? This is like doing business with a praying mantis. You get seduced, and then eaten alive afterwards?

Get real, would ya? You and I are both like guys who had this rich neighbor - Xerox - who left the door open all the time. And you go sneakin' in to steal a TV set. Only when you get there, you realize that I got there first. I got the loot, Steve! And you're yellin'? "That's not fair. I wanted to try to steal it first." You're too late.
[first lines]

I don't want you to think of this as just a film - some process of converting electrons and magnetic impulses into shapes and figures and sounds. No. Listen to me. We're here to make a dent in the universe. Otherwise, why even be here? We're creating a completely new consciousness, like an artist or poet. That's how you have to think of this. We're rewriting the history of human thought with what we're doing.
Right. Well, Steven, at the moment I'm a touch more worried about getting light on the actress. Do you know what I mean?
You know how you survive? You make people need you. You survive because you make them need what you have. And then they have no where else to go.
Steve - it is Steve, right? You say this gadget of yours is for ordinary people. What on earth would ordinary people want with computers?

Now, we know that IBM has set up this place to complete head-on with Apple, and that you're gearing up to come out with a personal computer that will wipe them out. So we can get you an operating system.
What kind of operating system?
It's called DOS.

This is amazing. Not just amazing, it's historic. It should be taught in all the history books. Hung and framed in the National Gallery or something, because this is the instant of creation of one of the greatest fortunes in the history of the world. I mean, Bill Gates is the richest guy in the world because of what started in this room. And you wanna know what else? It wasn't exactly smoke and mirrors, but we didn't have anything! I mean, not a damn thing! Here we were, this two-bit little outfit, telling IBM we had the answer to their problems. The DOS? The Disk Operating System? To make all those zillion IBM computers compute? We didn't remotely own anything like what Bill was selling them. Nada. Zip.
I think I had a date tonight with Ann.
I thought she was away on business.
She is.
Then how can you have a date?
Well, I go to a movie here, and then she goes to the same movie in Denver, and then we talk on the phone about it afterwards.
Jeez Bill, I hate to see what happens when you two have sex.
[cackling]
There may be a few... similarities.
Similarities? Similarities? Try theft.
The profits are in the computers themselves, not this software stuff.
Steve Wozniak's employee number one, you're number two.
Wait a minute. I'm employee number one. Woz?
Doesn't matter to me.
I'm employee number one around here.
I'm not saying anything. I wasn't implying anything.
All right, then I'll be zero. Woz, you can be number one. I'll be zero. Okay?
Steve, why do you care what I call the baby?
Because I don't want the baby named Rainbow! Or Orisha, or Ravi Shankar, or any other name like that.
You're the only guy I know who pays strippers to put their clothes on!
Why do you want to buy my operating system?
We think we might be able to, uh, mess with it, and, uh, resell it.
Who to?
We've got some people we're sorta talkin' to. Some of 'em don't really want it known what we're doin' with 'em and they made us sign a secrecy agreement.
And you're offering us...?
Fifty thousand.
Dollars?
Dollars.
What's he talking about, the Altair? I never had a problem with the Altair - 'til I tried to use it!
Maybe in a past life I was a poet - or an artist.
Think they're hookers?
Either that or motel inspectors. I saw one of them go into the room next to ours about a dozen times yesterday.
You are putting poison into your body.
That's french fries, man. You know, all-American food?
That's what I'm talking about.
Come on, I can't eat like you do. Eatin' fruit all the time? That's weird.
It's not weird. It's pure.
Where's your beard?
In the bathroom sink. I shaved it off.
Well, how come?
'Cause banks don't like beards.

Microsoft? Nobody I knew ever heard of Microsoft. Or Bill Gates. I mean, they were nobodies. But then we were all nobodies, which was perfect for us. Because all the respectable, straight-arrow guys were busy doing what they always do, which is be respectable. Which meant the rest of us could run around acting like crazies, which is what we did best. I miss those days.
Steve, I'm worried. About what's happening. All the "them versus us" stuff. Macintosh versus Apple II.
You don't understand, John. People need a cause.
Steve, all cars have steering wheels, but no one tries to claim that the steering wheel was their invention.
Sometimes not knowing how crazy something is, is a good thing.
Those guys think they're revolutionaries. They're not revolutionaries, we are.
We are?
Bill, I don't know if it's the clothes on the floor or you, but something in here definitely needs to be hosed down.
Bill, you're gonna have to come up with a better pickup line because asking her her SAT score is NOT going to do it!

[laughs]
Eureka! I created a program that can play blackjack.
Chris, you've been here two days, and you're into blackjack?
Yeah, so?
So we've got work to do.
I don't understand - how does the hardware handle the mouse/cursor display?
No, it's all right here in the software...
Enough!
[angrily mashes button, closing the Macintosh display]
Sorry, Steve.
There's no use torturing our guests with what they can't have.
What, like I have to have a moustache?
A suit! You actually bought a suit!
You're stealing from us!
Bill, why did you tell them we had an operating system? We don't have a thing to sell them now, you know? We're dead!
We're not dead, you're going to give us that miracle, right, Paul?
Huh? Oh yeah, right...
Come on, I thought you said you knew a guy we could buy an operating system from!
I said I "sort of" know one.
Sort of? Don't tell me "sort of"! I just told IBM!
Sort of...
Are you sure this thing is even gonna work?
If it doesn't catch fire.
Don't even joke.
I've always wondered what it was like for Steve. Ever since we were kids, everything he ever did was somewhere between a religious experience and some sort of crusade, like with this
[Macintosh]
commercial...
[last lines]
It's going to be very interesting, you know... you and me, working together?
Yeah. Yeah, it sure is.
Honest to God, Ballmer. You have no culture.

Oh yeah, like you go around reading Plato! You're the only guy I know who can make furniture out of Playboys. Look, you got enough to make a chair. You don't have to worry about 'em moving around, 'cause they're all stuck together...
[laughs at his own joke]
They're all stuck together!
Yes, I'm listening! I am so sick of your abusiveness. That's all you know. Tearing people down, throwing tantrums. You miserable son of a bitch.
Steve... you demolished that guy.
Are you a virgin?
Steve, come on.
How old were you when you first got laid?
I don't - I don't...
Steve, will you leave him alone?

[to Jobs]
All I'm doing now is being a brake pedal for you as you're heading for the wall.

[seeing first version of Microsoft Windows]
I made a mistake. I trusted. I believed. "Family?" Maybe a Mafia family. You turn your back, and you get whacked.

[about their first prototype]
They hated it.
Woo hoo!
[hugging him, dancing about]
